body: Friendly reminder to @sureshsubbiah  to review this change again
Thank you @selvaganesang for patiently waiting for and for encouraging review. I promise to complete mine in the next 24 hrs.

Can you please describe with more details regarding the original issue in the JIRA.  It is unclear to me the scenario with 2 floating IPs. Let's hold off on the merge until we understand the original issue that will help us understand the changes done

I don't familiar with the license issue. Is there any document saying we can not use? As i know if we want to make any changes on the source code, it should involve license issue. We also did use Python which is GPL license in DCS pom.xml. What do you think or any body we could ask?

1. config ha env
2. sqstart
3. use iptables to down master node's network, (iptables -I INPUT -s hostname -j DROP)
4. sleep for 300 seconds
5. backup-master take over the master role
6. recover network (iptables -I INPUT -s hostname -d DROP)
7. pdsh $MY_NODES ifconfig|grep 23400 will have 2 results, one is the down dcsmaster and another is the backup-master
actually , the old dcsmaster is still in while loop when network recover, so there will have 2 working dcsmaster.
Looked a pom.xml in Apache Spark and some of the dependencies are not from Apache. So I think it might be ok( correct me if i am wrong).

http://apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-x

The DCS dependency you mention is jython-standalone, which has a different license, and is regferenced in our license file(s).
@selvaganesang, do you have any further comments? Or should I go ahead and merge this change?
@hegdean, are you happy with this change now? Should I merge it?

Could you please add some queries that use these functions to some regression test? Don't sleep too long, though :-) You may need to add a filter to mask out the random digits in the UUIDs.

Also, you probably found this out already, Trafodion does not give any guarantees over where it places these functions. Let's say you have a table t with 1000 rows and you issue this query:

select uuid(), sleep(1) from t;

There is no guarantee that you get 1000 different uuids back or 1000 clones of the same one. Also, the query may sleep some amount other than 1 or 1000 units. The outcome depends on the query and maybe other factors such as CQDs. This makes these functions not as useful as they seem and that's why the designers of the SQL language have stayed away from non-deterministic functions and functions with side-effects.

If you create scalar UDFs for such functions you have some limited control via the "NOT DETERMINISTIC" attribute, as you probably have already seen in TRAFODION-2912. That is the better approach, but it comes with a performance penalty.

Here is a use case that many people may want to have, so it would be good to allow it:

create table t(id char(36) not null default uuid());

Again, it is not easy to guarantee that every row inserted into the table will get its own uuid. So, at second thought, don't allow this unless you ensure that you get a unique column this way.

Another example:
```
select * from t1 join t2 on t1.ts = t2.ts
where t1.ts between unix_timestamp() - 1000 and unix_timestamp() - 800;
```
Queries like this may give you complete nonsense back. This is because the Trafodion compiler assumes all ItemExprs are deterministic.

As long as you are willing to live with these problems that's probably ok. Many times you will get what you want. When you update the SQL Reference Manual you should make it very clear that these functions have undefined behavior.

Thanks Hans, yes, the uuid() and sleep() may have issues as you described. The major usage of uuid is to be used as the default function for column definition. But you are right, it could be used in a select list or anywhere a function is allowed and the output is deterministic. Let me add these in the documentation and add some regression test. The reason I didn't add tests is because they are random, but as you suggested, the output can be filtered out.
For unix_timestamp(), it is just like the currenttimestamp(), as I understand, the approach trafodion using is to have them using same value id in a single query, and each occurrence of them should invoke once and represent identical value. But I didn't strictly test it. Let me add test case, and do more check on this.
These are very excellent and knowledgeable comments. I never thought in this way. And it is very good for me to learn the design reasons behind all these. :-) 
Let me try again, and since they are implemented in MySQL, Let me try to make it as much same as in MySQL and document it clearly.

Yes, as I expected, the results will vary. If you want to use uuid() as the default in DDL, that is one case where we might be able to give a guarantee, with some special code. Maybe you can look at the code for identity columns and the code that generates the SYSKEY and take a somewhat similar approach for uuid. However, since identity columns and SYSKEY are actual columns, you won't be able to solve it in exactly the same way. It might have been easier to initialize a column to a uuid in a different way, without using a function (and maybe you can under the covers handle the uuid default that way). You can then still keep the function and just document that it behaves in unpredictable ways.

Hi, Hans,

You are right!
Let me change the uuid() implementation and make sure it will be same in a single query. And do a new commit.

And there is another requirement for random() function, which is by nature need to vary for each occurrence, but we should call it random(), not uuid(). So let me fix uuid.

Thanks,
Ming

Hi, @zellerh , I have updated the uuid code to make it evaluate once per query. So the 1000 rows will have same uuid() if in a single query , and also:

select uuid(), uuid() from dual;

Maybe I still not correctly understand the issue here. But here is what I want to make sure.

Not implemented yet for default clause, but I wish it work as demo below:

create table tt1 (c1 int, c2 timestamp default current, c3 varchar(100) default uuid() );

select * from NULLFIRSTTEST;
C1
-----------
          1
          2
          ?
          ?


upsert into tt1(c1) select c1 from NULLFIRSTTEST;

select * from tt1;
C1           C2      C3
-----------  -------------------------- --------------------------

          2  2018-02-16 23:06:58.732655  1d502632-b177-4f8f-8ce9-b66309f895e4

Current code should already support this behavior when uuid is allowed for default clause.

But Hans, Maybe what you really means is still NOT what I changed? 
If we evaluate UUID() for each row, above four rows should return four different UUID, what you worried before is those 4 UUID cannot guaranteed to be unique, if there are thousands of them? The current code use libuuid, it was said in the man page that it will generate global unique values.

So please help to review the change again, and let's make clear what should be the correct behavior here. If we cannot make it, I would like to make it clear in the document.

Thanks,
Ming
+1 looks good for me as well.

The idea of limiting PID_MAX in RMS infrastructure serves two purposes
a) To limit the pre-allocated pid array size
b)  To make the installer aware that the unusually large pid_max is configured on the system

 Trafodion is made to tolerate the unusually large pid_max configuration without bringing the node down. However, these processes don't participate in RMS making it devoid of the benefits RMS brings to them like detecting what queries are run from these process, cancel the query etc. , Hence, it  is recommended that PID_MAX configuration in RMS is in sync with the /proc/sys/kernel/pid_max.  It is expected the /proc/sys/kernel/pid_max is changed to a reasonable number.   

So, I don't expect the log storm to happen.

Ideally we should not see cases where RMS and /proc/sys/kernel/pid_max differ, but in practice I would assume that this does happen occasionally. If we create thousands of ESPs, won't that be a problem, as Dave pointed out? I like Dave's solution of putting some flag into the shared segment, to avoid too many log messages. You could limit it to something like 100, so people examining the log would still notice the first 100 as an unusual event. I assume that "get statistics for rms" will report a problem when RMS is not configured correctly for the pid_max on at least one of the nodes? This could be another reason for marking the shared segment.
In Esgyn's internal testing, it is felt that this restriction of limiting PID_MAX in RMS infrastructure needs to be removed entirely. I will be working to remove this restriction soon.

Great, that's even better! My gut feeling is the same. People aren't changing PID_MAX for fun, and when they (have to) do it, they do not expect EsgynDB to have big issues with such a change. Sorry you have to go from a simple array to something more complicated.

However, I believe configuring a node with more than 128K active processes is a stretch by itself even with larger memory configuration.  It could be because some application is  running amok producing many threads or process or the application is having problems with pid recycling.  I added this comment just to record by opinion, but I will work to remove this restriction soon.
Is there a JIRA for this change? Could you please add it? Thanks.

Hi @traflm ,

About your question: No, I'm not worried that different calls to uuid() will return the same value (that might not happen in my lifetime :-). My main concern is that methods like RelExpr::pushdownCoveredExpr() (the main method that decides where to evaluate an expression) may decide to evaluate the uuid() function on the parent rather than push it down. The uuid() function requires no inputs, so it can be evaluated anywhere, and the normalizer is completely free to choose a location for the evaluation. This is all done based on heuristics, and the code gets very complicated, especially when VEGies are involved.

Another problem comes from how the SQL standard is defined. SQL is a descriptive language and leaves the optimizer lots of choices. Let's say I have a table T with n rows:

```
select *
from T x, T y
where x.a = y.a + sleep(1)
```

The standard says that _effectively_, we form the Cartesian product of the tables (T and T, in this case) and evaluate the where clause on it. If you take this literally, we would have to sleep n ** 2 seconds for this query. However, we generally assume ItemExprs like + and = and also sleep() to be deterministic and without side-effects, so we use something like a hash join that evaluates the where clause much less often than n**2 times. But, a function with side-effects like sleep() violates the definition of "effectively". This is just a very simple example.

Here is another:

```
with x as (select uuid() from T)
select count(distinct *)
from (x union all x) x2
```

If table T has n rows, what's the answer to this query, n or 2n? As you probably know, with Trafodion you probably get 2n by default, but set some CQDs and suddenly you may get n.

These are somewhat esoteric examples, but if you get into more complex queries like TPC-DS, you may run into similar issues quite frequently.

Again, I'm fine with these functions as long as we make it very clear that they are not well-defined and should not be used beyond very simple queries.

What we would need to do this right are "not deterministic" and "external action" attributes of functions. We have "not deterministic" for UDFs, but we don't honor this attribute in every case.

Yes. Forgot to add the JIRA in the title. Here is the JIRA
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TRAFODION-2963

To @zellerh's comments: Thinking about sleep(), I wonder if maybe the desired semantics are to execute it just once per query? If so, treating it like current_timestamp is appropriate. Evaluate it in the master, at the beginning of execution.

Yes, Dave, I think sleep() once per query is what I should change. 
Thanks Hans for the very excellent explanation and details! And I will revert the uuid() back to evaluate multiple times per query and make it clear in the documents, these functions should only be used in very few cases with careful notice. And I will check those function attributes. Let me describe these in the document. And I will update the regress test to make it make more sense ..

Hi, Hans,
I tested on MySQL 5.7 UUID() is evaluated once per row(), And in Oracle sys_guid() is evaluated once per query. Since this is non-ANSI functions, we have to choose the behavior by ourselves.
Since this JIRA is to simulate the MySQL, so I would like to evaluate uuid() once per row, it makes more sense if the original idea is to use it as default value of a column, and uniqueness will be a desired result.
But I will make it clear in the documentation that the usage of uuid() is 'non-deterministic' and should not appear in JOIN, UNION ect. As you mentioned, the non-deterministic flag is now only for UDR, so I will leave the functions as it is for now, and we can change it when Trafodion has evolved to check non-deterministic flag everywhere , and I will have a new JIRA for the documentation of these.

Thanks,
Ming

hi, @zellerh , @DaveBirdsall 
I have updated the code again.
This time: 
make the sleep() as input value, and can only be evaluated once. Make sleep() only accept literal input. 
update test002, make sure sleep() only eval once per query, not per row.
update test002, make sure uuid will be distinct and match the row number, so make sure it is eval once per row and no conflict.

create JIRA for later documentation: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TRAFODION-2968
make sure these functions can only be used in very simple queries as they designed for.

Please help to review again. Thanks.
